name: MGBreastDensityCS
title: Mammography Breast Density CodeSystem
description: Mammography breast density values code system.

concept.definition:
[PR] Almost entirely fat

[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
Unless an area containing cancer is not included in the image field of the mammogram,mammography is highly sensitive in this setting.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Scattered areas of fibroglandular density

[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
(historically, there are scattered fibroglandular densities).It may be helpful to distinguish breasts in which there are a few scattered areas offibroglandular-density tissue from those in which there are moderate scattered areas offibroglandular-density tissue. Note that there has been a subtle change in the wordingof this category, to conform to BI-RADS® lexicon use of the term "density" to describethe degree of x-ray attenuation of breast tissue but not to represent discretemammographic findings.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Hetrogeneously dense

[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
It is not uncommon for some areas in such breasts to be relatively dense while otherareas are primarily fatty. When this occurs, it may be helpful to describe the location(s)of the denser tissue in a second sentence, so that the referring clinician is aware thatthese are the areas in which small noncalcified lesions may be obscured. Suggestedwordings for the second sentence include:"The dense tissue is located anteriorly in both breasts, and the posterior portionsare mostly fatty.""Primarily dense tissue is located in the upper outer quadrants of both breasts;scattered areas of fibroglandular tissue are present in the remainder of the breasts."
Valid for the following modalities: MG.

[PR] Extremely dense

[Bi-Rads® Atlas — Mammography Fifth Ed. 2013]
The sensitivity of mammography is lowest in this density category.The Fourth Edition of BI-RADS®, unlike previous editions, indicated quartile rangesof percentage dense tissue (increments of 25% density) for each of the four densitycategories, with the expectation that the assignment of breast density would bedistributed more evenly across categories than the historical distribution of 10% fatty,40% scattered, 40% heterogeneously and 10% extremely dense. However, it has sincebeen demonstrated in clinical practice that there has been essentially no changein this historical distribution across density categories.
Valid for the following modalities: MG.
